b"Send delivery scams packing! If you\xe2\x80\x99ve done your Christmas shopping online, you\xe2\x80\x99ll now be swamped with text and email delivery updates. But keep a close eye on them. Fake delivery notices are being reported by customers right now and we don\xe2\x80\x99t want anyone to be caught out. Please share this with loved ones who may not be on social media.

*What to look out for*
Any message stating a driver has tried to deliver your parcel and asking you to click a link to reschedule. Then, being asked to enter sensitive info like your date of birth, mobile number and card details. If you submit personal data, scammers could use it to call you up or access your bank account. 

*How to stay safe*
- Double and triple check delivery messages. 
- Make sure they link up to genuine orders. Does the message mention the goods you ordered or the company you ordered from?
- Check the message addresses you by name rather than just your email address or a basic \xe2\x80\x98Dear customer\xe2\x80\x99. 
- Look for tell-tale signs such as spelling and grammar mistakes.
- Don\xe2\x80\x99t submit any personal info like date of birth, card details or mobile number. Genuine delivery messages don\xe2\x80\x99t ask for this and don\xe2\x80\x99t ask for payment to re-deliver parcels.
- Delete anything dodgy, especially if you\xe2\x80\x99re not expecting a delivery, and if you\xe2\x80\x99re not sure, don\xe2\x80\x99t click the link. Delete the message and get in touch with the retailer you purchased from.

To stay up to date on the latest scams, visit our website and search 'fraud guide'.

b'All set to bag the best Black Friday deals? :shopping_bags_selector:

Well, if a deal seems like an unbelievable bargain, then it\xe2\x80\x99s probably a scam. And watch out if you\xe2\x80\x99re asked to pay by direct bank transfer. b"No one likes a fake. Make sure you\xe2\x80\x99re clued up on spotting scams ahead of #BlackFriday and you\xe2\x80\x99ll still have a chance to grab some of the best deals.

#TakeFive to read our tips below:
.
Check who you're really buying from
.
How much do you really know about the seller? 

Do your research by checking out the seller/company customer reviews on other review sites. And if you discover there\xe2\x80\x99s no physical address or phone number, then it could be a scammer.

Remember that just because a site uses a co.uk web address, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily mean it\xe2\x80\x99s located in the UK or a genuine seller.
.
Pay safe, use your card
.
Did you know that paying by credit or debit card is one of the safest ways to shop online? 

If a seller asks you to pay by direct bank transfer, don\xe2\x80\x99t do it. If it turns out to be a scammer, you\xe2\x80\x99ll lose your money. Stick with your card and you\xe2\x80\x99ll be safe.
.
Don't hand over your personal information
.
You wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give someone your PIN at an ATM, so don\xe2\x80\x99t hand over personal information to suspicious looking websites.

And if you\xe2\x80\x99re asked for your bank login details, to move money from your account, your card reader codes or to allow remote access to your device, you\xe2\x80\x99ll know it\xe2\x80\x99s a scam.
.
Don't get tricked by your inbox
.
Inbox full of Black Friday emails? 

Keep a close eye on what you\xe2\x80\x99re opening, as it could be a scammer with a fake offer. Beware of offers and free gifts before clicking a link in an email, it could land you with a nasty computer virus. So remember to delete any suspicious emails.

b'Keep an eye out for card reader scams :backhand_index_pointing_down:

Being asked for your card reader code is a classic tactic used by criminals pretending to be from your bank. \xe2\x80\x8b

You wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give someone your PIN or card at an ATM. And you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hand out your passwords to strangers. So make sure you don\xe2\x80\x99t hand out your card reader code.\xe2\x80\x8b

#TakeFive to think whether the person calling you is genuine and don\xe2\x80\x99t forget the other signs of impersonation scams: \xe2\x80\x8b

b"We\xe2\x80\x99re very proud of our Royal Bank colleague Sheena Hales who has been awarded a British Empire Medal (BEM) for her role in transforming our conference centre at Gogarburn into a temporary food and clothing bank. \xe2\x80\x8b

Sheena\xe2\x80\x99s quick thinking and determination to make a difference sparked a chain of events that led to the foodbank being staffed, made COVID-19 secure and ready for operation in under 24 hours. Since opening, the centre has delivered essential food parcels on a weekly basis to Trussell Trust, and has also helped distribute new clothing, books and water to local communities in central Scotland. \xe2\x80\x8b

BEMs are awarded for hands-on service to the local community that has made a significant difference. And while they\xe2\x80\x99re usually announced in April, this year\xe2\x80\x99s honours list was delayed until October to include the efforts of people like Sheena who have supported local communities through the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. \xe2\x80\x8b

For Sheena it was seeing everyone pull together to set up the foodbank that really mattered; \xe2\x80\x9cWhilst I am honoured, it has been a complete team effort and so I can't take responsibility alone for what we have achieved.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x8b

Well done to Sheena and everyone else involved."

b"Victims of domestic abuse, including financial abuse, may be finding it harder to seek the help they need. Help us support the #YouAreNotAlone campaign by learning to spot the warning signs of financial abuse and spreading the message in your community.

How to get help: Call 999 if in immediate danger. If you can\xe2\x80\x99t speak and are calling from a mobile, listen to the operator and when prompted, dial 55 to connect to the police, who will help.
.

The five signs:

1.	Unusually restricted access to finances
As people are home together, an abuser might have greater oversight of spending. Abusers may also use the instability of the current situation to take even greater control of finances.

2.	Unable to access financial support
Look out for someone who says that their partner is preventing them from speaking to their mortgage provider, utility company or another contract provider to negotiate a payment holiday or other form of financial support available during COVID-19.

3.	Struggling to work from home
Abusers may use the lockdown to interfere with someone's ability to work by insisting that they are are responsible for childcare, disinfecting the home or deny them of the equipment they need such as a laptop.

4.	Not staying socially connected
An abuser may use current isolation measures to cut someone off further from sources of support. If someone you can about is in touch less frequently or you hear a change in their tone, this may be a sign that an abuser is limiting their contact with others.

5.	Prioritising buying non-essentials
Someone experiencing financial abuse might prioritise a particular bill or buy expensive items to meet the demands of the abuser, who may be spending more time at home. For example, they may pay for extra mobile phone data over a water bill."

b"4 of the most common Coronavirus (COVID-19) scams
.
Here\xe2\x80\x99s what you need to know to keep yourself safe \xe2\x80\x93 scroll through to read more :backhand_index_pointing_up:
.
***Please help us reach people who aren't on social media - talk to friends and family and help keep them safe.***
.
Be alert to suspicious phone calls, texts or emails about Coronavirus from anyone claiming to be from the bank or other trusted organisations.  We\xe2\x80\x99ll NEVER ask you for your full PIN or password, card reader codes, or ask you to move money from your account.
.
Fake cures
.
These are emails that claim there\xe2\x80\x99s a cure that\xe2\x80\x99s been covered up by various governments. There are a number of variations of this email, but it\xe2\x80\x99s likely to ask to you click a link to receive information about the cure. Do NOT click this link as it\xe2\x80\x99ll take you to a webpage that captures your bank login information.
.
World Health Organization impersonation scams
.
These emails appear to be from trusted organisations such as the World Health Organization (WHO). They\xe2\x80\x99ll contain an attachment, claiming to have safety measures to combat coronavirus. But the attachment actually infects your device with malware that monitors your online activity and captures your information. Remember, never download attachments from emails you\xe2\x80\x99ve received out of the blue.
.
Coronavirus tax refunds
.
You\xe2\x80\x99ll receive an email saying you\xe2\x80\x99re entitled to a tax refund due to coronavirus. The link will take you to a fake government website that will capture your financial information. Remember, HMRC won\xe2\x80\x99t contact you by email about tax refunds and you can report emails like this to phishing@HMRC.gov.uk
.
Bitcoin payments
.
Emails claiming to be from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) or the World Health Organization (WHO), may request Bitcoin payments. You\xe2\x80\x99ll be told that you\xe2\x80\x99re donating towards a cure or paying for essential coronavirus information. These emails are fraudulent and you won\xe2\x80\x99t receive anything for payments made. NEVER click a link or make a payment to emails you\xe2\x80\x99ve received out of the blue.
.
